meanings.def: the small hard seeds of food plants such as wheat, rice, etc.; a single seed of such a plant
examples: Russia sold 12 million tons of grain abroad last year.
America’s grain exports
The journal reports that eating whole grains protects against diabetes.
grain of something a few grains of rice
Grain production has been falling in recent years.
There were just a few grains of corn left.
The government intends to import only five per cent of the country's grain.
The peasants had ceased to sow grain.

meanings.def: a small hard piece of particular substances
examples: a grain of salt/sand/sugar
I got a grain of sand in my eye.
There isn't a grain of truth in those rumours.
If he had a grain of sensitivity he wouldn't have asked her about her divorce.

meanings.def: a small unit of weight, equal to 0.00143 of a pound or 0.0648 of a gram, used for example for weighing medicines
examples: The analysis showed a few grains of arsenic in the solution.

meanings.def: the natural direction of lines in wood, cloth, etc. or of layers of rock; the pattern of lines that you can see
examples: along/across the grain to cut a piece of wood along/across the grain
This wood has a beautiful natural grain.

meanings.def: how rough or smooth a surface feels
examples: wood of coarse/fine grain

meanings.def: to be or do something different from what is normal or natural
examples: It really goes against the grain to have to work on a Sunday.

meanings.def: used to warn somebody not to believe something completely
examples: If I were you, I'd take everything he says with a grain of salt.

idioms.def: to be or do something different from what is normal or natural
examples: It really goes against the grain to have to work on a Sunday.

idioms.idiom: take something with a grain of salt
idioms.def: used to warn somebody not to believe something completely
examples: If I were you, I'd take everything he says with a grain of salt.
